tn.text: Paul asks the believers to pray for him and his companions.
Paul uses the word "now" to mark a change in topic.
Here "brothers" means fellow Christians, including both men and women. AT: "brothers and sisters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: the word of the Lord may rush and be glorified
tn.text: Paul speaks of God's word spreading as if it were running from place to place. AT: "that more and more people will soon hear our message about our Lord Jesus and honor it" (UDB)  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that God may save us" or "that God may rescue us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"for many people do not believe in Jesus"
"who will strengthen you"
"Satan"
"We have faith" or "We trust"
Paul describes the Lord motivating Christians to love God as if the Lord were guiding them down a path. AT: "help you know " (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a metaphor for the emotions or will, which control love and faithfulness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to the love of God and to the endurance of Christ
tn.text: Paul speaks of God's love and Christ's endurance as if they were destinations on a path. AT: "how much God loves you and how much Christ has endured for you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul gives the believers some final instructions about working and not being idle.
Paul uses this word to mark a change in topic.

tn.ref: in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ
tn.text: "by Jesus' authority"
Here "brothers" means fellow Christians, including both men and women. AT: "brothers and sisters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
Here "our" refers to all believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"is lazy and refuses to work" (UDB)
"to act like Paul and his fellow workers" or "to behave like Paul and his fellow workers"

tn.ref: We did not live among you as those who had no discipline
tn.text: Paul uses a double negative to emphasize the positive. This can be stated as a positive. AT: "We lived among you as those who had much discipline" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"we worked during the night and during the day" or "we worked all the time"

Paul emphasizes how hard his circumstances were. Difficult labor implies work that requires great effort. Hardship implies they endured pain and suffering. AT: "in very difficult circumstances" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: We did this not because we have no authority
tn.text: Paul uses a double negative to emphasize the positive. This can be stated as a positive. AT: "We certainly have authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Here "walk" stands for behavior in life. AT: "some live idle lives" or "some are lazy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Meddlers are people who interfere in the affairs of others without being asked to help.
"in a quiet, peaceful, mild manner." Paul exhorts the meddlers to stop getting involved in other people's affairs.
Paul uses this word to contrast the lazy believers with the hardworking believers.
The word "you" refers to all the Thessalonian believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "brothers" means fellow Christians, including both men and women. AT: "brothers and sisters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
To "lose heart" is an idiom that means to get tired, weary, or discouraged. AT: "do not be discouraged" or "do not grow weary" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Notice who he is. AT: "publicly identify that person" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: so that he may be ashamed
tn.text: Paul instructs believers to shun lazy believers as a disciplinary action.
Paul makes closing remarks to the believers at Thessalonica.

tn.ref: May the Lord of peace himself give you
tn.text: You can make explicit that this is Paul's prayer for the Thessalonians. AT: "I pray that the Lord of peace himself gives you ... " (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "himself" emphasizes that the Lord will personally give peace to believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: This is my greeting, Paul, with my own hand
tn.text: "I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand"
Paul makes it clear that this letter is from him and is not a forgery.
